metadata.title: Highly efficient synthesis of isoprene from methyl tert-butyl ether and formaldehyde over activated carbon supported silicotungstic acid catalysts

Highly efficient synthesis of isoprene from methyl tert-butyl ether and formaldehyde over activated carbon supported silicotungstic acid catalysts SaiSai Wang a Xingkun Chen a * Yuan Tan a Ziang Zhao b Wenshao Yang a * Chuanqi Huang a Xuepeng Wang a MiaoMiao Chen a Zhongnan Du a Yunjie Ding a b c ** a Hangzhou Institute of Advanced Studies, Zhejiang Normal University, 1108 Gengwen Road, Hangzhou, 311231, China Hangzhou Institute of Advanced Studies Zhejiang Normal University 1108 Gengwen Road Hangzhou 311231 China aHangzhou Institute of Advanced studies, Zhejiang Normal University, 1108 Gengwen Road, Hangzhou 311231, China. b Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian, 116023, China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road Dalian 116023 China bDalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, China. c The State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian, 116023, China The State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road Dalian 116023 China cThe State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, China. ⁎ Corresponding author at: Hangzhou Institute of Advanced studies, Zhejiang Normal University, 1108 Gengwen Road, Hangzhou, 311231, China. Hangzhou Institute of Advanced studies Zhejiang Normal University 1108 Gengwen Road Hangzhou 311231 China ⁎⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract In this contribution, we reported the liquid single-stage synthesis of isoprene from methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) and formaldehyde over activated carbon supported silicotungstic acid (STA/AC) catalysts. In comparison with the corresponding homogeneous STA catalysts, the STA/AC catalysts exhibited much higher activity of the prins condensation reaction under the same conditions. The results could be attributed to the highly dispersed STA, the relative weaker acidity resulting from the strong interaction between STA and AC and the structural collapse of STA. Additionally, the catalyst could be reused at least 3 times with only a slight decrease of activity. The physical and chemical properties of the STA/AC catalysts were characterized by means of DRIFT, HRTEM, HAADF-STEM, NH3-TPD, XRD, XPS and TG techniques. The excellent catalytic reactivity and easy recycling advantages make the STA/AC catalyst to be an attractive candidate of the prins reactions in the future. Keywords Isoprene MTBE Silicotungstic acid Prins reaction Heterogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction Isoprene is an important precursor and useful chemical molecules in the field of various synthetic rubbers, elastomers, and resins etc [1–3]. Presently, a significant amount of isoprene is mainly obtained from the C5 fraction of naphtha steam cracking. However, this method requires a number of expensively extractive distillation steps. Thus, a facile route to synthesis of the isoprene has to be further developed. The prins condensation of formaldehyde with isobutene appears as the most attractively alternative technology. The industrial process based on this route typically consists of two stages: 1) the liquid synthesis of 4,4-dimethyl-1,3-dioxane (DMD) from isobutene and formaldehyde using aqueous sulfuric acid or phosphoric acid as the catalyst, 2) the gas phase decomposition of DMD to isoprene using solid phosphoric acid catalysts (Scheme 1 a). However, this two-stage process has a number of disadvantages involving economical, technological, and environmental issues, such as low yields, separation and corrosion problems [4]. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop a single-stage process for synthesis of isoprene using heterogeneous catalysis. A lot of efforts have been made to synthesize the isoprene via the single-stage prins reaction employing isobutene and formaldehyde as the feedstock over various solid catalysts including metal oxides [5,6], zeolites [7–11], phosphates [12–14], and silicotungstic acids [15,16] (Scheme 1b). However, the prins reaction for the synthesis of isoprene is frequently hindered by the rapid deactivation due to fast coke formation during reaction over the above mentioned catalysts. Thus, a number of approaches have been explored to give a liquid-phase single-stage process for the isoprene synthesis under mild condition. MTBE is a commonly additive of gasoline in the past decades because it aids in the complete combustion of fuel by supplying oxygen. Whereas now it has been proved to be a potential environmental pollutant and a possible human carcinogen at high concentrations. Therefore, it is banned from adding to gasoline in many countries [17]. Hence, the transformation of MTBE to high valuable products will be necessary and urgent. Recently, Prasassarakich et al. reported the synthesis of isoprene from MTBE and formalin over heteropolyacids (HPA) and its cesium salts catalysts (Scheme 1c) [18,19]. Among the available catalysts, HPA, as acidic forms of polyoxometallates, exhibited excellent catalytic performance in both homogeneous and heterogeneous systems owing to their well-defined structure and widely modifiable acidity [20–24]. In comparison with conventional solid acid catalysts, the HPA possesses stronger Brönsted acidity and higher proton mobility [25–30]. Previously, the majority of the catalytic applications used the homogeneous Keggin HPAs as the catalyst since it had advantages of structural mobility and multifunctionality. However, this catalyst was easily soluble in polar solvents. Thus, the catalyst was difficult to separate and recycle. The salts of HPAs owned better property of water resistance, in which the protons were substituted by large monovacant cations (such as NH4 +, K+, Cs+). However, the low reaction rate of the catalysts largely restricted its further application. Therefore, to realize a recyclable and highly efficient catalyst, immobilization of HPA on the water-insoluble supports with high surface area might provide an accessible way [31,32]. In this study, we firstly proposed the highly efficient synthesis of the isoprene from MTBE and formalin using activated carbon supported silicotungstic acid (STA) as the catalysts (STA/AC) (Scheme 1d). It was found that the STA/AC catalysts exhibited much higher activities than that of the corresponding homogeneous STA catalysts under the same reaction conditions. Furthermore, the reusability of the STA/AC catalysts was detected. The effects of the temperature, the MTBE/formaldehyde ratio, the H2O/formaldehyde ratio and the STA loadings on the activity and selectivity were also investigated. The STA/AC catalysts were characterized by means of adsorption-desorption of N2, TG, XRD, HRTEM, HAADF-STEM, EDS-mapping, DRIFT and NH3-TPD. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Heteropolyacid PTA (H3PW12O40·nH2O), PMA (H3PMo12O40·nH2O), and STA (H4SiW12O40·nH2O) were purchased from Sinopharm company. Activated carbon (AC) was supplied by Tangshan United Carbon Technology Co. Ltd. China. MTBE (>99 wt %, Thermo Fisher Scientific (China) Co., Ltd.), Formalin (formaldehyde 37∼38 wt %, methanol 10 wt %, Sinopharm), cyclohexane (99.5 wt %, Sinopharm) and deionized water were used in our experiments. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Before preparing the catalyst, the AC samples should be pretreated. AC was washed in a solution of 0.1 mol/L NaOH and then treated with 0.1 mol/L HCl to remove the soluble acidic and alkaline impurities [33]. The AC supported HPAs catalysts were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method according to the following procedure: AC was impregnated with an aqueous solution of HPAs at room temperature. Then the samples were calcined in a flow of N2 at 300 °C at a ramp temperature of 2 °C min−1 for 2 h [26]. The sample was denoted as x-STA/AC, where x represents the percentage loading of the STA. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The texture properties of the samples were measured by adsorption-desorption of N2 at 77 K using an AutoSorb-1 instrument. Prior to the measurements, the samples were outgassed for 6 h at 200 °C. The pore size distribution was determined from the adsorption branches using NLDFT (the nonlocal density functional theory) method. Power x-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were performed on a Panalytic X’Pert PW3040 diffract meter with Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA). The patterns were taken in a scanning angle (2θ) range of 10°∼90° at a speed of 2°·min−1. The temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) experiments were performed on Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 with a MS detector. Prior to the analysis, about 70 mg of the catalyst samples were added into a U-type quartz tube reactor and then the sample was heated in a flow of helium at 250 °C for 1 h. After being cooled down to 50 °C, the sample was saturated with NH3 under 50 °C for 2 h. Then, the sample was treated in a flow of helium at 50 °C for 1 h. Finally, NH3-TPD signal was recorded from 100 °C to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1. Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform (DRIFT) spectra of the samples were recorded on Thermo Scientific iS50 spectrometer. The spectra were recorded in the standard form of KBr pellets in the range of 650∼4000 cm−1 with 32 scans with a resolution of 2 cm−1 under room temperature. The microstructure of the samples was further observed by high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) at 200 kV with a JEM-2100 F field emission TEM. The thermal stability of the catalysts was tested by thermogravimetry (TG) measurement on a Setaram Setsys 16/18 analyzer from room temperature to 1000 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 and a N2 flow rate of 40 mL·min−1. High-angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) was performed on JEOL ARM200 F equipped with double aberration correctors and a cold field emission gun, which was operated at 80 kV. XPS spectra were carried out on an ESCALAB 250Xi Alα radiation. 2.4 Catalyst evaluation In a typical reaction test, a 60 ml stainless-steel autoclave was charged with 0.1 g x-STA/AC catalyst, 13.5 mmol MTBE, 1.8 mmol formaldehyde, 4.65 g water, 4.65 g cyclohexane, and then the reactor was sealed. After replaced three times with N2, the reactor was pressurized to desired pressure with N2 at room temperature. The contents were heated to 150 °C and stirred for 180 min. Afterwards the reactor was cooled down to room temperature with ice-water and the liquid samples were centrifuged to isolate the catalyst. The products were analyzed by gas chromatography (Agilent-7890B) equipped with a capillary column of HP-5 and an FID detector using ethanol as an internal standard. Sodium sulfate titration method was used for determining formaldehyde in the reaction mixture. First, the NaOH solution was added into the reaction mixture to eliminate the effect of HPA until the pH was about 9.8. Then the sodium sulfite solution was mixed with the above solution to react with formaldehyde. At last, the mixture was titrated with HCl until pH was 9.8. Isoprene yield, formaldehyde conversion, and isoprene selectivity were calculated by using Eqs. (1), (2), and (3), respectively. (1) Isoprene yield = moles of isoprene formed initial moles of formaldehyde × 100 % (2) Conversion = moles of formaldehyde converted initial moles of formaldehyde × 100 % (3) Selectivity = moles of isoprene formed moles of formaldehyde converted × 100 % Hot-filtration test: First, a parallel reaction was performed under the same conditions of previous test without MTBE and formaldehyde. Then the reactor was cooled down and the solid catalyst was filtered off. After that, MTBE and formaldehyde were added into the above resulting filtrate and the mixture was placed under the same reaction conditions as the original reaction. Afterwards, the reaction mixture was cooled down to room temperature and analyzed by means of gas chromatography. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts structure and composition The textural properties of AC and STA/AC with different STA loadings were studied by means of adsorption-desorption of N2. The obvious type IV isotherms with H4 hysteresis loops indicated the coexistence of micro- and mesopores (Fig. 1 a). The pore size distribution curves calculated by nonlocal density functional theory method (NLDFT) were displayed in Fig. 1b, which further confirmed the hierarchical structures. According to previous reports, the hierarchical porous structure facilitated the mass transfer process which might accelerate the reaction rates [34]. The surface characteristics such as surface area and pore volume were shown in Table 1 . It was obvious that the surface area and pore volume decreased with increasing of the STA loadings. A similar result was also observed by Oball et al. [35]. That may be attributed to the partial blockage of the pores on the support by the active STA species. However, the pore size was maintained at 0.56∼0.57 nm, indicating that the STA was well dispersed inside the channels of AC support. In addition, even the 20-STA/AC catalyst exhibited the relatively high surface area and large pore volume of 808 m2  g−1 and 0.38 cm3 g−1, which was much higher than that of the STA itself (Fig. S1). The decrease of the micropores in the used 7-STA/AC catalyst was observed from the pore diameter diagram in Fig. 1, which might be due to the blockage of the deposited carbon on the surface of the catalyst during the reaction process. The DRIFT spectra of the x-STA/AC samples with different STA loadings and the bulk STA were presented in Fig. 2 . In comparison with the AC support, three major bands at 1028 cm−1, 879 cm-1 and 796 cm−1 on the STA/AC catalysts could be assigned to the Si-O, WO and WOW vibrations, respectively [36]. And the intensity enhanced with increasing STA loadings. The fact that the characteristic bond of WO remained unchanged regardless of the treatment implied that the Keggin structure of the STA was substantially intact on the surface of the supported x-STA/AC catalysts [26]. These results were consistent with the STA/AC samples reported by Badday et al. [26]. In addition, the characteristic peak of the WO vibration at 980 cm−1 was absent on the x-STA/AC catalysts. That suggested a bonding truly occurred between the STA and the AC support. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of bulk STA and the x-STA/AC catalysts with different STA loadings. It was found that all samples displayed two diffuse and broad diffraction peaks at 2θ of 15-30° and 40-50° except for the pure STA. The broad peak could be assigned to amorphous carbon [37]. What’s more, for all of the STA/AC catalysts, no pattern of any bulk STA crystal phase was observed. It suggested that the STA particles on the surface of AC might be too small to be detected or highly dispersed. This observation was in line with the conclusion reported by Atia et al. [38]. Fig. 4 shows the HRTEM and HAADF-STEM images of the 7-STA/AC catalyst. Obviously, most of the STA nanoparticles were evenly distributed on the surface of the AC support, suggesting a uniform distribution of the acidic sites. In addition, the average particle size of STA was about 1.6 nm, which was statistically measured from the HRTEM images. The result agreed well with the studies of XRD. Element distribution of the 7-STA/AC catalyst was determined by the HAADF-STEM-EDS-mapping, which revealed that the highly dispersed elements (C, O, Si and W) were well integrated on the catalyst (Fig. 4). Thus, it could be inferred that the elements of O, Si, W were in close contact, and the STA structure was not destroyed. It was also consistent with the DIRFT observation. The highly dispersed STA species on the AC support were believed to take an important part in the prins condensation reaction of the heterogeneous catalyst. The acid property of the STA/AC and other HPA catalysts were studied by means of NH3-TPD. It showed that the solid acid sites could be clarified into three types, the weak site (100∼200 °C), the moderate site (250∼400 °C) and the strong site (450∼650 °C) based on the NH3-TPD profiles using the mass detector [35]. Obviously, The NH3-TPD spectra for STA/AC catalysts are very different from that of pure STA. They showed desorption peaks in the lower temperature ranged from 150∼450 °C, which corresponding to the weak and moderate acid sites. For all the x-STA/AC catalysts, the area of the weak acid sites is higher than that of the moderate. The weak acid sites might result from the Keggin structure of STA collapses [27,39–42]. The appearance of moderate acidic sites might be ascribed to the interaction between oxygen-rich hydroxyl groups, ketones and carboxyl groups on the AC surface and STA [16,32]. The total acidity of the x-STA/AC catalysts were presented in Table 1. It was evident that the total amount of acid sites increased with increasing the STA loadings. And the total acidity on the used STA/AC catalyst decreased, which might be due to the coverage of acidic sites by the deposited cokes during reaction. It was also in line with the decrease of their surface area. Furthermore, the NH3-TPD spectrum of different AC supported HPA catalysts exhibited similar desorption peaks, suggesting that the similar interaction was presented on all of the supported samples in this work (Fig. 5 b). However, the 7-STA/AC catalyst showed a comparable higher amount of acidity than that of the 7-PTA/AC and 7-PMA/AC samples, which exhibited the value of 122 μmol, 97 μmol and 89 μmol NH3/gcat, respectively. The fitting results of C 1s and O 1s spectra suggested that the AC support utilized in this work contained functional groups of −COOH, –C=O and −OH, which could interact with STA (Fig. S2) [32]. In addition, the XPS spectra (Fig. S3) of Si 2p and W 4f showed that the binding energy of Si and W slightly increased after STA being supported on the surface of AC. That indicated an interaction was present between STA and AC support. TG analysis of the bulk STA, the AC support and the x-STA/AC catalysts were conducted to examine the thermal property. The TG curves (Fig. 6 ) of all samples shows a weight loss at about 100∼200 °C, ascribing to the removal of physically absorbed solvent. The weight-loss step of the bulk STA was observed at a temperature range of 400∼500 °C, corresponding to the decomposition of Keggin anion. Nevertheless, in case of the x-STA/AC catalysts, the major weight-loss occurred between 700–900 °C, which might owe to the cleavage of oxygenated carbon groups on the surface and the decomposition of molecular STA. Furthermore, the weight-loss between 700–900 °C increased from 12.1%–17.5% with increasing the STA loadings from 3% to 20 %. It could be concluded that the interaction between STA and the AC support might improve the thermal stability of STA. Similar research was reported by Z. Obal and T. Doğu [43]. 3.2 Catalytic activity According to previous reports, the synthesis of isoprene by prins condensation from olefins and aldehydes was mainly through the protonation of formaldehyde by attacking olefins to form carbocation intermediates. The precursor of the reaction product was mainly 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol (MBD), 4,4-dimethyl-1,3-dioxane (DMD) and methyl-butenols (MBO). DMD could be decomposed into the target product of isoprene. However, the produced isoprene and other precursors in reaction mixture can also interact with isobutene or formaldehyde to produce other by-products. Replaced isobutene with MTBE as the stock feed in the same reaction process maybe inhibit further reaction. 3.2.1 Synthesis of isoprene in solvent-free systems The synthesis of isoprene from MTBE and formaldehyde over the STA/AC catalyst was first performed in a solvent-free system. The effects of the STA loadings, reaction time, temperature and MTBE/formaldehyde ratio on the performances of prins condensation were shown in Fig. 7 . The yields of the isoprene increased from 7.9 % up to 17.2 % with the STA loadings increased from 3% to 7%. However, it decreased dramatically while the STA loadings were further increased. This might be caused by the condensation of isoprene and precursor with formaldehyde to form the pyran compound and other heavy products at the strong acid sites [9], resulting in the decrease of the pore volume as well as the surface area of STA/AC and the disconnection between the reactants and the active acid sites [44]. Fig. 7b displayed the effect of MTBE/formaldehyde ratio on the prins reaction over the STA/AC catalyst. The catalytic activity increased dramatically when the MTBE/formaldehyde ratio was raised. It reached a maximum yield of 17.2 % at ratio of 7.5. The reason for this phenomenon might be that the excessive formaldehyde would further react with the isoprene to produce side products. As a typical consecutive reaction, the reaction time played a significant role in determining the products distribution. Fig. 7c showed that the highest yield of the isoprene was obtained at 180 min and a decrease was observed when the reaction time was prolonged. It might be attributed to the decomposition of isoprene or more side reactions. Fig. 7d showed the effect of temperature on the behavior of transforming MTBE and formaldehyde into isoprene. The isoprene yield reached a maximum of 17.2 % at 150 °C. When the reaction temperature was further increased, the yield of isoprene decreased due to the decomposition of isoprene. 3.2.2 Synthesis of isoprene in solvent system As we know, the synthesis of isoprene from MTBE and formaldehyde using homogeneous HPAs catalysts were largely dependent on the solubility of isobutene. When increased the solubility of isobutene in organic phase and/or separated the isoprene from aqueous phase, the reaction rates could be accelerated correspondingly. In this work, the effect of solvent was investigated in present heterogeneous system (Table 2 ). Obviously, the yields of isoprene increased sharply when cyclohexane was added in the reaction. And the optimal cyclohexane/MTBE mass ratio was about 4.0, since a decrease of the reactants concentration would reduce the reaction rates when much more cyclohexane was added. In addition, the yield of isoprene would be further increased when both cyclohexane and water were simultaneously added to the reaction system. The isoprene yield increased to 43.7 % with the water/MTBE mass ratio increasing to 4.0. Whereas the reaction rates decreased when the water/MTBE mass ratio was continuously increased to 5.0. This might be attributed to the worse solubility of MTBE in the organic phase when large amount of water was added. Table 3 presents the performance of the synthesis of isoprene from MTBE and formaldehyde over various catalysts in a cyclohexane-water system. The highest activity was achieved in case of H3PO4 among all the homogeneous catalysts (Table 3, entries 1–7). Due to the strong protonation process of formaldehyde and isoprene, the optimized acid catalysts could reduce side reactions and leaded to an improvement in the yield of isoprene. Tribasic acids (e.g. H3PO4) exhibited a small dissociation constant in comparison with the monobasic (e.g. HCl) and dibasic (e.g. H2SO4) acids. What’s more, a higher isoprene yield was obtained when much more STA was added (Table 3, entry8). According to this result, we might propose that the prins reaction process would rely on the proper acid strength or dissociation constants and the total acidities for Brønsted acid. Generally, immobilized homogeneous catalysts onto insoluble supports often caused a decrease in catalytic activity and selectivity due to the low exposure of active sites and mass transfer resistance. However, the HPA/AC heterogeneous catalysts exhibited much higher activity than that of the homogeneous HPA catalysts under the same reaction conditions (Table 3 entries 5–7 and 9–11). The yield of isoprene increased in the order of: 7-PMA/AC < 7-PTA/AC < 7-STA/AC. It can be explained from the following reasons. 1) The high surface area and large pore volume of the HPA/AC catalysts facilitated the mass transfer process and made it easy to establish a connection between reactants and active sites. Thus, it improved the reaction rates. 2) The hierarchical structures of the AC supported catalysts might benefit for the selective synthesis of isoprene. 3) The adsorption of the reactants prefers to occur on the interface between the heterogeneous catalyst and the reaction system, which accelerated the reaction rate [45]. 4) The relative weaker acid sites were presented on the catalyst due to the interaction between HPA and the AC support. Based on the characterization results of NH3-TPD, it is reasonable to propose that the acid strength played a significant role in determining the reaction rates. Furthermore, the commonly used heterogeneous acids, such as 7-STA/SiO2, Hβ, MCM-22 and Polystyrene sulfonic acid (PPS) were also investigated (Table 3 entries 11–15). Obviously, it showed that the yields of isoprene were 35.9 %, 33.1 %, 22.9 % and 8.5 % for 7-STA/SiO2, Hβ, MCM-22 and PPS, respectively, which were lower than that of 43.7 % for 7-STA/AC. In light of the previous results, control experiments were conducted to investigate the effect of temperature and MTBE/ formaldehyde ratio on cyclohexane-water system. Fig. 8 a showed the influence of temperature on the catalytic performance. The conversion of formaldehyde was about 89.7 % at 130 °C. When temperature was raised to 150 °C, the conversion increased to 98.8 %. At the meantime, the selectivity of the target isoprene increased from 24.9%–44.3%. Further increased the temperature to 170 °C would not improve the activity, but the selectivity decreased dramatically. These results proved that the formation of by-products such as pyran and methoxy-methylbutenes produced by further reaction between the isoprene precursor or isoprene and formaldehyde was truly occurred and impacted on the selectivity. The effect of the MTBE/formaldehyde ratio on the performance of the prins condensation reaction was shown in Fig. 8b. The conversion of formaldehyde and the selectivity of isoprene increased from 75.9∼99.3 % and 13.3∼44.3 %, respectively, with the MTBE/formaldehyde ratio in the range of 3∼7.5. When increased the ratio to 10∼15, the conversion of formaldehyde (98.7∼99.3 %) and the selectivity of isoprene (44.3∼42.2 %) preserved. This result proved that the appropriate ratio of MTBE/formaldehyde played crucial the excellent catalytic performance. 3.3 Catalyst stability and reusability The stability of the supported catalyst during the prins reaction is of great concern for the heterogeneous catalysts. Thus, the reusability of the STA/AC heterogeneous catalyst for synthesis of isoprene with MTBE and formaldehyde was studied here (Fig. 9 ). The catalyst was readily separated by simple centrifugation and then washed with cyclohexane to remove any non-polar impurities. The cleaned catalyst was dried at 100 °C for 2 h and weighed. A minimal catalyst loss during the separation process was supplied with the fresh catalyst. Then the catalyst was reused for next run of the reaction. Obviously, in the fourth run, a yield of 33.6 % was obtained using the reused catalyst, which was relatively lower than that of the first recycle of 43.7 %. To glean information about the slightly deactivation of the STA/AC catalyst, the spent catalyst was characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, TG, NH3-TPD and ICP-OES techniques. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and the surface characteristics of the spent STA/AC catalyst were shown in Fig. 1 and Table 1. The results displayed a slight decrease in the surface area and pore volume of the sample, which might be attributed to the coke deposition during the reaction process. TG analysis of the recovered catalyst after the fourth cycle showed that a major weight loss of 4.08 % in the temperature range between 300∼700 °C occurred which might be caused by the decomposition of coke (Fig. S4) [16]. The NH3-TPD analysis result of the spent STA/AC catalyst was presented in Table 1. The result revealed that the total acidity of the spent STA/AC catalyst after the first circle was 114 μmol NH3/gcat, which was lower than that of the fresh catalyst of 122 μmol NH3/gcat. Furthermore, the total acidity of the spent STA/AC catalyst after reusing three times was about 107 μmol NH3/gcat. To investigate the STA leaching problem, ICP-OES was used to detect the content of W specie on the 7-STA/AC catalyst. It was found that the amount of W on the fresh and spent catalyst were 5.3 % and 5.2 %, respectively, which showed a negligible amount of leaching. In addition, a hot-filtration test was conducted. When the insoluble catalyst was removed from the solvent by filtration, no isoprene was found in the reaction solution. Thus, we speculated that the slight deactivation of the STA/AC catalyst might be partly resulted from the coke deposition and the minimal catalyst loss. Conditions: 7-STA/AC catalyst 0.1 g, temperature 150 °C, time 180 min, MTBE 13.5 mmol, formaldehyde 1.8 mmol, water 4.76 g, cyclohexane 4.76 g. 4 Conclusion In summary, the isoprene was efficiently synthesized from MTBE and formaldehyde in a liquid single-stage synthesis using the STA/AC heterogeneous environmental benign catalysts. The STA/AC catalysts exhibited much higher activities than that of the homogeneous STA and strong Brønsted acid such as sulfuric acid, hydrochloric acid and phosphoric acid in prins reaction under the same conditions. This could be explained by the strong interaction between STA and AC support. In addition, the high surface area, large pore volume and hierarchical pore structures of the STA/AC played a significant role in enhancing the reaction rates. The catalytic activity was totally influenced by the acid strength, solvent, temperature, MTBE/formaldehyde ratio and the amount of STA. Additionally, the existence of the carbonaceous species deposited on the surface of catalysts was responsible for the slight loss of the reaction rates. All these results indicated that the one-step liquid synthesis of isoprene from MTBE and formaldehyde over the STA/AC catalysts could be a potential sustainable and green route. coredata.dc:description: In this contribution, we reported the liquid single-stage synthesis of isoprene from methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) and formaldehyde over activated carbon supported silicotungstic acid (STA/AC) catalysts. In comparison with the corresponding homogeneous STA catalysts, the STA/AC catalysts exhibited much higher activity of the prins condensation reaction under the same conditions. The results could be attributed to the highly dispersed STA, the relative weaker acidity resulting from the strong interaction between STA and AC and the structural collapse of STA. Additionally, the catalyst could be reused at least 3 times with only a slight decrease of activity. The physical and chemical properties of the STA/AC catalysts were characterized by means of DRIFT, HRTEM, HAADF-STEM, NH3-TPD, XRD, XPS and TG techniques. The excellent catalytic reactivity and easy recycling advantages make the STA/AC catalyst to be an attractive candidate of the prins reactions in the future.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient synthesis of isoprene from methyl tert-butyl ether and formaldehyde over activated carbon supported silicotungstic acid catalysts
